video.title_en: Antonio Meucci - The true inventor of the telephone

summary.text_en: The Italian immigrant Antonio Meucci designed and built an 'electromagnetic telephone' in the late 1850s (reportedly as early as 1857), which he called the 'Telettrofono'. He built the device to connect his basement workshop to his wife, who was an invalid bedridden on the second floor. He filed a 'patent caveat' (a temporary patent) in 1871, but in 1874, due to extreme poverty (and injuries from an explosion), he failed to pay the $10 renewal fee, and the caveat lapsed. Just two years later, Bell (`bell_telephone_1876`) filed his patent.
key_points_en: Built to communicate with his invalid wife
Lost his 1871 patent caveat due to poverty (failed to pay $10 fee)
Recognized by US Congress in 2002 for his 'pioneering work'

story.text_en: Meucci's device worked on the 'electromagnetic' principle (`faraday_induction_1831`), the same as Bell's patent and Gray's design. He built his first model (reportedly) in 1857. In 1871, he filed his caveat and tried to demonstrate his invention to Western Union, but his models were (allegedly) 'lost'. In 1874, he couldn't afford the $10 renewal. In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell (who was working in a lab funded by Western Union) filed his formal patent. Meucci sued Bell, but died before the case was resolved. In 2002, the U.S. Congress passed Resolution 269, formally recognizing Meucci's historic contributions to the invention of the telephone.

fun_facts.text_en: Meucci's tragedy is that he was '$10 away' from historyâ€”the renewal fee he couldn't afford to pay in 1874, largely because he was severely burned and impoverished by a steamship boiler explosion.

simple_explanation.text_en: Meucci was the 'first guy who actually did it'. As early as 1857, he built an electric telephone in his house to talk to his sick wife upstairs. He was poor, so in 1871, he only filed a 'temporary patent'. When that 'temporary' status *expired* in 1874 because he couldn't pay the $10 renewal fee, Bell swooped in two years later with a mathematically similar design, filed a *full* patent, and won the race.

applications.text_en: Meucci's device was the first 'intercom' system, designed for domestic voice communication.

impact.text_en: Although Meucci lost the legal and commercial battle to Bell, his 'Telettrofono' is recognized (especially in Italy and by the U.S. Congress) as being the 'first' true electric telephone. His story is the classic, tragic example of the race between 'invention' and 'priority' in patent law.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Faraday (his 'electromagnetic induction' was the physical principle for Meucci's telephone)

influenced.contribution_en: Bell (Meucci's lawsuit and designs were the greatest challenge to the priority of Bell's patent)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Antonio Meucci is the 'tragic father' of the telephone; the man who invented it first, only to watch another receive the credit and the fortune.

quiz.question_en: Why did Antonio Meucci lose his 'temporary patent' (caveat) in 1874?
options_en: He was defeated by Bell in court
He was too poor to pay the $10 renewal fee
He discovered his invention was flawed
quiz.explanation_en: It is a historical tragedy. Meucci, suffering from poor health and poverty, failed to pay the $10 renewal fee for his patent caveat in 1874, causing it to lapse. Two years later, Bell filed his full patent.
